awd_titl_txt: MRI: Acquisition of a high-performance computing instrument to support deep learning, modeling/simulation, and visualization for STEM

por.por_cntn:
This project's goal was to acquire and deploy a computing instrument to support deep learning, scientific modeling, and visualization applications. The resulting instrument is a supercomputer specialized to support applications needing highly-parallel computation that can be carried out using general-purpose graphics processing units (GPGPUs). It consists of a cluster of multiple (25) extremely high-performance GPUs from NVIDIA that can be used singly or as groups of GPUs via the University of Maine's research computing infrastructure. Users need not be members of the UMaine academic community; rather, the instrument is intended to be used by anyone in the region needing such resources.

The instrument became operational in 2022 and as of the summer of 2024, over 147 thousand GPU-hours of computing has been used by researchers and others in Maine and elsewhere in the region. Numerous projects in a variety of different areas have been supported, including: artificial intelligence (machine learning) basic research; applied machine learning for wildlife ecology; food science; physics; COVID-19 and influenza; analysis of genome-scale data; mechanical engineering; electrical & computer engineering; astronomy, and biology. Some of these projects have direct impact on the environment and societal well-being.

The instrument will continue to be available for users going forward through UMaine's ARCSIM (Advanced Research Computing, Security, and Information Management) unit. Those interested should contact ARCSIM directly (umaine.edu/arcsim).
